Income inequality in the United States is at an all-time high, surpassing even levels seen during the Great Depression, according to a recently updated paper by University of California, Berkeley Professor Emmanuel Saez. The paper, which covers data through 2007, points to a staggering, unprecedented disparity in American incomes. On his blog, Nobel prize-winning economist and New York Times columnist Paul Krugman called the numbers "truly amazing."
 
 Though income inequality has been growing for some time, the paper paints a stark, disturbing portrait of wealth distribution in America. Saez calculates that in 2007 the top .01 percent of American earners took home 6 percent of total U.S. wages, a figure that has nearly doubled since 2000.
 
 As of 2007, the top decile of American earners, Saez writes, pulled in 49.7 percent of total wages, a level that's "higher than any other year since 1917 and even surpasses 1928, the peak of stock market bubble in the 'roaring" 1920s.'"

Incomes are lower because the dollar is losing value.
 
 The dollar is losing value because the federal reserve is increasing the quantity of money (inflation).
 
 When there is inflation, the effects are not felt across all the economy at once.
 
 The winners are the initial recipients of the inflationary dollars; they receive the money before prices rise, and can use it to buy at a discount. Over the past 8 years, this group prominently featured banks, real estate buyers, and the associated industry.
 
 The losers are the people who receive those dollars at the end of the line (workers), or do not really receive them at all (people on fixed incomes). For them, the prices go up, their incomes remain the same, ie their real income declines.
 
 The winners are borrowers, and the losers are savers.
 
 Over the past 10 - 15 years the decline in the value of the dollar has been to some offset by rising productivity internationally, especially in China, bringing prices down.
 
 Prices should have been going up at a rate of perhaps 10% per year, but China's factories were producing more and more goods for consumption, cheaper and cheaper, so the prices only actually went up at a rate of say, 3% per year.
 
 The only way to address this issue is to end the federal reserve and cease a policy of inflation. The current regime has taken the opposite approach, granting the fed sweeping new powers while it pumps more and more inflationary dollars into the hands of banksters.
 
 This issue will not be resolved by taxing the rich, and I would suggest that people who dream of doing this are driven by malice rather than any genuine concern for the welfare of the people, given their utter failure to actually look into the causes of the problem.

I thought you were aware, Jo, I'm putting forward a viewpoint associated with the Austrian school.
 
 Key differences you might notice (I'm generalising slightly here):
 
 Austrians tend to advocate ending the fed, monetarists tend to want to target a specific monetary base growth rate, using the fed, or have some other scheme in mind, tending to be a bit on the conservative side (though not always).
 
 Monetarists believe that insufficient money creation is an evil, and can lead to recessions and depressions. Whereas the Austrians believe that the business cycle is the result of earlier inflation of the money supply. 
 
 Regarding the great depression for example, monetarists believe that the fed should have more aggressively inflated to counter the downturn, whereas Austrians don't believe that it should have responded with inflation at all.
 
 The federal reserve is currently a hybrid of monetarism and neo-keynesianism... I don't think it should exist.
 
 Monetarist's tend to believe "excessive" increases in the money supply cause inflation, Austrians believe *all* increase in the money supply is inflationary (price changes due to e.g. higher productivity, seasonal variations are not)
